AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
At the Movies: `Always'
DOC.TEXT: It's a curious irony that the leading commercial filmmaker of the cynical 1980s is a devout romantic. Throughout his career, Steven Spielberg has taken a sunshiny view of the human situation. His heroes, notably Indiana Jones, always triumph over insuperable odds. Life may hold its miseries, as in ``The Color Purple,'' but the struggle is always worth it in the long run. Even Spielberg's space visitors (``Close Encounters of the Third Kind,'' ``E.T. The Extra-Terrestrial'') prove benign. ``Always'' is Spielberg's most romantic film yet. The new movie stems from his fondness for the happy-ending films of the 1940s, especially ``A Guy Named Joe.'' That film provides the basis for ``Always,'' which is not likely to win the hearts of hardbitten critics but should appeal to the millions who embraced ``Field of Dreams'' early in 1989. In the new version, the air war of World War II has been supplanted by the battle against devastating forest fires. The sense of jeopardy is not the same, hence the dramatic tension is diminished. Richard Dreyfuss is the hotshot pilot of the tanker bomber base, taking risks that alarm his sweetheart, Holly Hunter, an air controller. He believes he is invincible, but during a daring rescue of his buddy, played by John Goodman, his plane explodes. Dreyfuss finds himself on a grassy oasis amid a burned-out forest, getting instructions from an angel _ Audrey Hepburn in a white designer pantsuit. The guardian angel tells Dreyfuss his mission: to return to Earth unseen and help Hunter overcome her grief and pass on his flying prowess to another pilot. Enter Brad Johnson, a klutzy flier who needs Dreyfuss' help but is handsome enough to sway Hunter's heart. Spielberg lavishes all his craft on ``Always,'' and no director makes better use of the camera. The fire scenes have a frightening immediacy, and the flying is among the best in recent times. The fault lies in the script, credited to Jerry Belson and the late Diane Thomas but seemingly the work of many hands. Consistency of tone is lacking, and the plot has certain confusions, as though important scenes had been cut. The cast performs admirably. Dreyfuss displays the solidity of Spencer Tracy, who originated the role. Hunter is highly effective, especially after she drops her down-home cuteness. Goodman neatly fits his large frame into the Ward Bond-Alan Hale kinds of roles. Johnson has the looks of a '40s screen idol and is likely to become a star of the '90s. ``Always'' is a Universal-United Artists picture produced by Spielberg, Frank Marshall and Kathleen Kennedy. The rating is PG, probably for mild swearing and excitement. Running time: 121 minutes.
